block.p: INTERNATIONAL

The Japanese have begun to retaliate against the 63 percent U.S. tariff on the most advanced screens for laptop and notebook computers, with some companies saying they will stop sending the screens to the U.S. [ Page D1. ]

OPEC agreed to a Saudi proposal to increase the group's total production ceiling by more than a million barrels a day, which would keep oil prices at their current moderate range, about $19. The accord was opposed by several OPEC countries. [ D1. ]
INTERNATIONAL

The Japanese have begun to retaliate against the 63 percent U.S. tariff on the most advanced screens for laptop and notebook computers, with some companies saying they will stop sending the screens to the U.S. [ Page D1. ]

OPEC agreed to a Saudi proposal to increase the group's total production ceiling by more than a million barrels a day, which would keep oil prices at their current moderate range, about $19. The accord was opposed by several OPEC countries. [ D1. ]
The European Community became the first industrialized region to propose a clean-energy tax in an attempt to curb worldwide emissions of carbon dioxide. [ D3. ]
India's Commerce Minister announced that his Government had approved two joint ventures between American multinationals and local companies, and preliminary plans for two others. [ D10. ]
Exporters began buying more than $200 million worth of grain and soybeans for delivery to the Soviet Union after commercial banks flooded Soviet authorities with offers to lend money. [ A9. ]

A three-way dispute involving the Administration, Senate and House over a ban on imports from foreign companies that sell chemical and biological weapons has stalled the $5 billion State Dept. authorization bill. [ A14. ] THE ECONOMY
Clearing the way for the Administration's effort to remove restrictions on banks, a House panel presented a compromise that could permit the repeal of Glass-Steagall. [ D1. ]
Factory orders for durable goods and sales of existing homes fell last month, reports show, prompting concern about the sectors that were expected to lead the economy out of recession. [ D2. ]
At the Harvard Business Review, things seem worse, not better, since Rosabeth Moss Kanter has been in charge. [ D1. ]
William M. Isaac has parlayed his years as a top banking regulator into a profitable business advising banks on how to deal with regulators. [ D1. ]
Three in 10 Americans say they or someone in their household have at some time stayed in a job they wanted to leave mainly to keep health benefits, a poll shows. [ A1. ] COMPANIES
As Galeries Lafayette prepares to open its first American store, questions arise about whether the fashionable French store can survive some stiff competition. [ D1. ]
Delta's proposed purchase of most of Pan Am's trans-Atlantic routes was tentatively approved by the Transportation Dept. [ D4. ] MARKETS
Blue-chip stocks fell slightly in rudderless trading, while smaller issues reached record levels for the second time in four sessions. The Dow dipped 8.05, to 3,021.02. [ D10. ]
Customers returned to regular bidding patterns at an auction of $9.25 billion in five-year Treasury notes, with more than 93 percent submitted by New York-based primary dealers. [ D18. ]
Copper futures prices jumped to a five-month high amid reports of spreading violence in Zaire. [ D19. ] The dollar fell in quiet domestic trading after rising overseas. [ D19. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS
If the ideal deal is win-win, Todd Products appeared headed for success when it established an employee stock ownership plan. Talking Deals. [ D2. ]
The most extensive campaign ever for the most expensive Mercedes-Benz line ever will introduce the redesigned S-Class as "the car of a lifetime." Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [ D8. ]
Time Warner's stock rose after its chairman, Steven J. Ross, told shareholders of "serious and meaningful discussions" for an alliance with a foreign partner. Market Place. [ D10. ]
